awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Fuels, Additives and Emissions in Low-Temperature Combustion
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-1553366, Goldsmith

One strategy to reduce the engine exhaust emissions is to control the combustion at a temperature lower than the conventional value. Low-temperature compression-ignition engines represent a new class of internal combustion engines that could meet the stringent and imminent fuel economy requirements. Engineers typically add additives to the fuel to improve the engine performance. The most commonly used additive contains nitrogen, yet the fate of fuel-bound nitrogen in low-temperature combustion is poorly understood. Although some of the ultimate combustion byproducts formed by nitrogen-containing additives in these engines may be comparatively benign, other byproducts are highly toxic, and the relative yield of these toxic byproducts is not known. The goal of this proposal is to discover the fate of fuel-bound nitrogen in advanced engines. Over the course of five years, the PI will combine novel experimental, theoretical, and modeling techniques to provide quantitative measurements and kinetic predictions for the combustion byproducts of nitrogen-containing additives under engine-relevant conditions. This research will provide engineers with the tools to quantify the interactions between additives and transportation fuels in internal combustion engines, and to predict how changes to the additive, the fuel, or the engine will affect the emissions. Additionally, this research will benefit atmospheric chemists by improving their forecasts of smog and related problems. Finally, the PI will develop a series of educational modules that illustrate how changing the structure of a fuel changes its combustion properties, and will create hands-on design projects in which students build different combustion devices.

The most widely used fuel additive in low-temperature compression-ignition engines is 2-ethyl-hexyl nitrate (2EHN). The hypothesis is that a significant percentage of the nitrogen in 2EHN exits the cylinder as hydrogen cyanide and other highly toxic compounds. To test this hypothesis, shock tube experiments, electronic structure theory, and kinetic modeling studies will be combined to quantify the various nitrogen containing products and establish the reaction pathways that produce them. Additionally, the PI will collaborate with engineers at Argonne National Laboratory to develop computational models to predict how 2EHN will interact with real-world transportation fuels, such as n-heptane, iso-octane, and toluene. Many key pathways in low-temperature compression-ignition engines are kinetically controlled, so these engines produce different combustion byproducts than conventional, high-temperature engines. Knowledge of these pathways is particularly important for fuel additives that contain nitrogen. The majority of our understanding of nitrogen chemistry is limited either to high temperatures in excess of the thermal NOx limit, or low temperatures in the atmosphere. This proposal will fill in a crucial gap in our understanding of nitrogen chemistry by elucidating the key chemical pathways for the oxidation and reduction of nitrogen containing species below the thermal NOx threshold.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to understand the interactions between additives and transportation fuels in internal combustion engines, to quantify the impact of these additives on the combustion properties of a fuel, and to predict how changes to the additive, the fuel, or the engine will affect the emissions. Low-temperature compression-ignition engines represent a new class of internal combustion engines that could meet stringent and imminent fuel economy requirements. These engines are highly sensitive to fuel composition, so engineers frequently use various additives to obtain the desired combustion properties. The comparatively low peak operating temperatures, however, present new challenges to the design of both the fuel and the catalytic converter. In particular, the ultimate combustion byproducts formed in low-temperature combustion from common fuel additives are poorly understood, and most likely, highly toxic.

In particular, our goal was to investigate the fate of fuel-bound nitrogen in low-temperature combustion. Our hypothesis was that a significant percentage of fuel-bound nitrogen exits the cylinder as hydrogen cyanide and other highly toxic compounds. To test this hypothesis, the PI combined shock tube experiments, electronic structure theory, and kinetic modeling studies to quantify the various nitrogen containing products and to establish the kinetic pathways that produce them.

Over the course of the project, the PI published 14 peer-reviewed manuscripts. Of these, 10 manuscripts were specific to fuel-bound nitrogen and NOx chemistry under engine-relevant conditions, and four additional manuscripts were on other aspects of hydrocarbon combustion chemistry. Included in the list are multiple papers on alkyl-nitrates, which are the most commonly used nitrogen-containing fuel additive for low-temperature combustion enhancement. In addition to measuring the decomposition rate and subsequent pyrolysis of two important alkyl nitrates, we also presented the first ever measured laminar flame speeds for any alkyl-nitrate. We also produced several theoretical and computational analyses on important reactions in NOx chemistry.

The award supported on PhD student for the entirety of their doctoral work, which included two research internships.

Although much work remains to be done on the subject, we provided the first rigorous, combined experimental and theoretical analysis on the decomposition, pyrolysis, and combustion of alkyl-nitrates. We provided a detailed understanding of how these additives interact with transportation fuels. We will continue to investigate the extent to which these additives can lead to unexpected, harmful combustion byproducts.

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2023
Modified by: Claude F Goldsmith

The goals of this project were to understand the  interactions  between additives and transportation fuels in internal  combustion  engines, to quantify the impact of these additives on the  combustion  properties of a fuel, and to predict how changes to the  additive, the  fuel, or the engine will affect the emissions.  Low-temperature  compression-ignition engines represent a new class of  internal  combustion engines that could meet stringent and imminent fuel  economy  requirements. These engines are highly sensitive to fuel  composition,  so engineers frequently use various additives to obtain the  desired  combustion properties. The comparatively low peak operating   temperatures, however, present new challenges to the design of both the   fuel and the catalytic converter. In particular, the ultimate  combustion  byproducts formed in low-temperature combustion from common  fuel  additives are poorly understood, and most likely, highly toxic.

In  particular, our goal was to investigate the fate of fuel-bound   nitrogen in low-temperature combustion. Our hypothesis was that a   significant percentage of fuel-bound nitrogen exits the cylinder as   hydrogen cyanide and other highly toxic compounds. To test this   hypothesis, the PI combined shock tube experiments, electronic   structure theory, and kinetic modeling studies to quantify the various   nitrogen containing products and to establish the kinetic pathways that   produce them.

Over the course of the project, the PI published 14  peer-reviewed manuscripts. Of these, 10 manuscripts were specific to  fuel-bound nitrogen and NOx chemistry under engine-relevant conditions,  and four additional manuscripts were on other aspects of hydrocarbon  combustion chemistry. Included in the list are multiple papers on  alkyl-nitrates, which are the most commonly used nitrogen-containing  fuel additive for low-temperature combustion enhancement. In addition to  measuring the decomposition rate and subsequent pyrolysis of two  important alkyl nitrates, we also presented the first ever measured  laminar flame speeds for any alkyl-nitrate. We also produced several  theoretical and computational analyses on important reactions in NOx  chemistry.

The award supported on PhD student for the entirety of their doctoral work, which included two research internships.

Although much work remains to be done on the subject, we provided the  first rigorous, combined experimental and theoretical analysis on the  decomposition, pyrolysis, and combustion of alkyl-nitrates. We provided a  detailed understanding of how these additives interact with  transportation fuels. We will continue to investigate the extent to  which these additives can lead to unexpected, harmful combustion  byproducts.
